title: After the Slop: Kyle McDonald Artist Lecture
time_location:
5:30 - 7 p.m.
College of Fine Arts 111
description:
They told us that making art is easy now, anyone can be creative. The machine ate our work, and they don’t need us anymore. Is it all AI slop from here on out? McDonald will give a brief history of how we got here, followed by examples of alternative approaches to using AI, beyond making more pictures of Donald Trump and Elon Musk making out on top of a bloodied planet.
Learn more about the event and speaker
Sponsored by the Sylvia and David Steiner Speaker Series, Frank-Ratchye STUDIO for Creative Inquiry, and School of Architecture CodeLab

title: Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives
time_location:
All Day (until June 1)
Hunt Library, Fourth Floor
description:
Settlement, industrialization, urbanization and redevelopment have each left a profound mark on the region’s built environment. The architecture bears testimony to the forces that shaped it, but buildings can only tell part of the stories. The histories of their conception, design, and construction are contained in the drawings and other documents shared between clients, architects, and contractors. These architectural records document an irretrievable past (for buildings demolished or left unbuilt), facilitate the preservation and reuse of extant buildings, and inform our understanding of our surroundings.

For the past 40 years, the Architecture Archives collections at Carnegie Mellon University have documented thousands of projects and the work of hundreds of designers. Records have been obtained from architects and their firms, families, property owners, and governments. This wide diversity of materials—preliminary sketches, renderings, specifications, photographs, publications and architectural models—helps piece together the rich history of Pittsburgh and the region.
Visit the exhibit website to learn more.

title: Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s
time_location:
All Day (until July 11)
Hunt Library Gallery
description:
Carnegie Mellon University entered the 80s as a well-respected regional university, but President Richard Cyert’s vision at the start of the decade would help turn CMU into an international leader in innovation, technology and the arts.
Before long, robotics, computer software and the Internet were integral parts of the campus. In 1984, Terregator—the “world’s first rugged, capable, autonomous outdoor navigation robot”—was completing its field testing at CMU. In 1985, the university began working with Apple founder Steve Jobs to develop part of the Mach operating system that ran on his NeXT computer workstation. In 1986, CMU launched the Andrew system, a joint endeavor between IBM and CMU to create the world’s first university-wide computer network and file system.
This growth led the university to develop a comprehensive video marketing plan that attracted the attention of high school guidance counselors, parents, and students from around the country.
By the decade’s end, the university experience had transformed in ways few could have imagined.
Learn more at https://library.cmu.edu/about/exhibits/cmu-1980s

title: AI-SDM Seminar Series: Deb Roy
time_location:
11:30 a.m. - 1 p.m.
Newell-Simon Hall 4305
description:
This interactive forum serves as a cornerstone for collaboration and knowledge exchange, convening the Institute’s investigators, postdocs, and graduate students alongside preeminent guest speakers from academia, industry, and government entities.
Each session presents an opportunity for remote and in-person attendees to delve into the Institute’s cutting-edge research at the nexus of artificial intelligence and societal decision-making. Sessions are further enriched by stimulating Q&A sessions and, of course, delectable refreshments for our dedicated physical audience. We invite you to engage, learn, and contribute to the advancement of AI for the betterment of society.
Speaker: Deb Roy, Professor of Media Arts and Sciences at MIT, Director of the MIT Center for Constructive Communication, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Learn more

title: Ram Navami
time_location: All Day
description: Ram Navami, which occurs on April 5, celebrates the birth of Lord Rama. To honor this day, Hindus clean and decorate their houses with fruits and flowers. They put an image of Rama as a baby in a cradle, and at midday, they remove the cover of the cradle and feed a special food (called Prasad) to him.

title: Libraries Workshop: Analyzing Scholarly Literature Using Bibliometrics
time_location:
Noon - 1 p.m.
Online
description:
This workshop will provide an introduction to bibliometric methods. Bibliometrics, or the use of tools and statistical methods to analyze published books and articles, can be a useful approach to understanding a body of knowledge and the way researchers are collaborating or publishing work on a topic.
We will cover the basics of gathering a dataset for bibliometric analysis using tools like Web of Science and Scopus; provide an overview of software tools for analyzing bibliographic data; and discuss examples of bibliometric analyses across a range of disciplines. The workshop is aimed at graduate students, staff and faculty researchers, but anyone is welcome to join.
This is Part 4 of the Advanced and Systematized Literature Review Methods workshop series. You do not need to have attended previous workshops in this series.
Learning Objectives:
Define bibliometrics
Describe the value of bibliometrics analysis in the context of your research
Use databases and other tools to gather a dataset for analysis that includes bibliographic metadata and citation data
Describe various tools that are used in bibliometrics analysis
Registration is required.

title: AI-SDM Seminar: Rayid Ghani
time_location:
11:30 a.m. - 1 p.m.
Newell-Simon Hall 4305
description:
This interactive forum serves as a cornerstone for collaboration and knowledge exchange, convening the Institute’s investigators, postdocs, and graduate students alongside preeminent guest speakers from academia, industry, and government entities.
Each session presents an opportunity for remote and in-person attendees to delve into the Institute’s cutting-edge research at the nexus of artificial intelligence and societal decision-making. Sessions are further enriched by stimulating Q&A sessions and, of course, delectable refreshments for our dedicated physical audience. We invite you to engage, learn, and contribute to the advancement of AI for the betterment of society.
Speaker: Rayid Ghani, Distinguished Career Professor in the Machine Learning Department and the Heinz College of Information Systems and Public Policy, Carnegie Mellon University
Learn more

time_location:
4 - 5:15 p.m.
Virtual via Zoom
Repeats weekly (to May 9)
description:
This weekly, unstructured group provides an opportunity to discuss stress and coping, misogynoir, oppression and privilege, intersectional identities, self-esteem, relationships, colorism, family, internalized racism and other topics of interest. Everyone’s agreement to maintaining the confidentiality of other members is essential!
Contact Kym Jordan Simmons, PhD (kyms@andrew.cmu.edu) to schedule a 30-minute pre-group meeting.

title: Day of Silence
time_location: All Day
description: The Day of Silence is a student-led national event to highlight the silencing and erasure of LGBTQ+ people. Participants take a vow of silence for the day, which ends with a Breaking the Silence rally to speak about their experiences and raise awareness of ways that schools and communities can be more inclusive.

title: Passover

Beginning at sundown the night before, rituals include telling the story, fasting from leavened bread, and participating in family seder meals. Many Jews keep kosher food restrictions during this festival and attend additional religious services.

title: Libraries Workshop: Tips for Writing Literature Reviews: Part 1
time_location:
2 - 3 p.m.
Online
description:
In this first part of the workshop, we will cover the goals of a literature review, how to select and scope a topic, and using library resources to find literature and take notes, including AI tools. While we will use examples from STEM, the tips can be applied to lit reviews in any subject area for course assignments or publication.
Note: Part 2 in this workshop series will focus on the actual writing of the review.
Registration is required.

title: CMU Drama Presents: Mary-Kate Olsen Is in Love
time_location:
8 p.m.
John Wells Video Studio, Purnell Center for the Arts
description:
Grace was supposed to have a certain kind of life. She did everything right, but now finds herself in an unfulfilling marriage to Tyler; her unemployed, video-game-addicted, stoner husband. Her now monotonous days consist of going to work, coming home and watching commercials. The only thing she has left is her manifestations of Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, who try to teach her how to be the perfect woman through consumerism, sexual objectification and medication, in hopes that Grace’s pursuit of perfection will satisfy her and quell the emptiness of her life.
However, Grace’s relationship with her metaphysical celebrity companions takes a bizarre turn when Mary-Kate falls in love with her, and the two go on a quest to New Zealand. Tyler, now alone, is compelled to enter his Call of Duty: Modern Warfare game to face his failures and find his purpose in his wife’s absence. Mary Kate Olsen Is in Love is a dark comedy that follows Grace on her journey to figure out what she actually wants out of her life in a world determined to tell her what will make her “happy.”
By Mallery Avidon
Directed by Anya Hilpert
Performances April 23-25
Tickets are free and can be reserved online beginning at noon the day before each performance.

time_location:
11:30 a.m. - 1 p.m.
Gates & Hillman Centers 6115
description:
This interactive forum serves as a cornerstone for collaboration and knowledge exchange, convening the Institute’s investigators, postdocs, and graduate students alongside preeminent guest speakers from academia, industry, and government entities.
Each session presents an opportunity for remote and in-person attendees to delve into the Institute’s cutting-edge research at the nexus of artificial intelligence and societal decision-making. Sessions are further enriched by stimulating Q&A sessions and, of course, delectable refreshments for our dedicated physical audience. We invite you to engage, learn, and contribute to the advancement of AI for the betterment of society.

The architecture bears testimony to the forces that shaped it, but buildings can only tell part of the stories. The histories of their conception, design, and construction are contained in the drawings and other documents shared between clients, architects, and contractors. These architectural records document an irretrievable past (for buildings demolished or left unbuilt), facilitate the preservation and reuse of extant buildings, and inform our understanding of our surroundings.

For the past 40 years, the Architecture Archives collections at Carnegie Mellon University have documented thousands of projects and the work of hundreds of designers. Records have been obtained from architects and their firms, families, property owners, and governments. This wide diversity of materials—preliminary sketches, renderings, specifications, photographs, publications and architectural models—helps piece together the rich history of Pittsburgh and the region.
Visit the exhibit website to learn more.

title: Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s
time_location:
All Day (until July 11)
Hunt Library Gallery
description:
Carnegie Mellon University entered the 80s as a well-respected regional university, but President Richard Cyert’s vision at the start of the decade would help turn CMU into an international leader in innovation, technology and the arts.
Before long, robotics, computer software and the Internet were integral parts of the campus. In 1984, Terregator—the “world’s first rugged, capable, autonomous outdoor navigation robot”—was completing its field testing at CMU. In 1985, the university began working with Apple founder Steve Jobs to develop part of the Mach operating system that ran on his NeXT computer workstation. In 1986, CMU launched the Andrew system, a joint endeavor between IBM and CMU to create the world’s first university-wide computer network and file system.
This growth led the university to develop a comprehensive video marketing plan that attracted the attention of high school guidance counselors, parents, and students from around the country.
By the decade’s end, the university experience had transformed in ways few could have imagined.
Learn more at https://library.cmu.edu/about/exhibits/cmu-1980s
